Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Coordinated Real-Time Traffic Management based on Dynamic Information Propagation and Aggregation under Connected Vehicle Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advances in wireless communication technologies have enabled communications among vehicles, and between vehicles and the associated infrastructure. These technologies can be significantly leveraged to enhance the safety and performance of current roadway transportation systems. This study seeks to understand how traffic information spreads among vehicles and between vehicles and the roadside infrastructure, and how that data can be efficiently collected and used to develop real-time traffic management strategies, so as to improve safety, mobility, and sustainability. Further, through the education programs at Illinois Institute of Technology and Purdue University, this study will aid the development of new skills for the workforce that can leverage these emerging technologies for innovative applications, and broaden research and educational opportunities for under-represented groups.

This study seeks to develop real-time coordinated traffic management strategies built upon dynamic information propagation and aggregation in connected vehicle systems. To achieve this goal, it investigates three interrelated research challenges: (i) information propagation dynamics, (ii) distributed information aggregation, and (iii) coordinated real-time traffic management. These methods bridge advanced scientific knowledge in computer science, transportation science, and operations research. Further, they adapt well-known and/or emerging concepts in traffic flow theory, network modeling, wireless communication, optimization theory, stochastic modeling, and algorithm design. The novelty of this research is highlighted through the holistic consideration of the unique features of a connected vehicle system: a distributed system with dynamic information propagating therein. At a fundamental level, the study outcomes will contribute to scientific knowledge and technologies for connected vehicle systems in the following aspects: (i) a better understanding of the interactions between information dynamics and traffic flow dynamics; (ii) the opening of a new research venue related to distributed information processing methods; and (iii) the understanding of real-time traffic management through the coordination of individual vehicle knowledge and centralized traffic control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Emergent technologies that enable vehicles on roads to talk to each other and with the surrounding infrastructure are providing opportunities for innovations that enhance traffic safety and reduce congestion, emissions and fuel consumption. Broadly classified under the umbrella of "connected vehicle systems," these technologies leverage vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communications to enable vehicles within a certain range to exchange information on traffic and infrastructure conditions, and vehicular dynamics. This project has focused on understanding how the time-dependent evolution of the traffic flow pattern, labeled traffic flow dynamics, affects and is affected by the information flow propagation in a road traffic network under connected vehicle systems. Doing so would enable the development of practical solutions that leverage V2V communications technologies to improve safety and mobility while enhancing environmental and energy sustainability.

The project outcomes include newly-developed models that allow transportation engineers and traffic management agencies to analyze how traffic information is propagated in time and space in a V2V communications-enabled traffic network based on the time-dependent traffic conditions. It would enable these agencies to then develop and disseminate real-time information-based solutions to road users to improve traffic conditions and reduce congestion in bottleneck areas of the traffic network. This would include what information to propagate, when to do so, and where to disseminate it so that the targeted road users could make more informed travel decisions that would improve traffic conditions, on average, for all users of that traffic network. Study results show that while uncoordinated V2V-communications can possible improve traffic conditions, coordinated solutions (for example, recommended by a traffic management agency) are required to fully benefit from the emerging connected vehicle technologies. Further, the results suggest that the time-depedent traffic flow pattern, including the percentage of V2V communications-capable vehicles in the traffic stream can significantly impact how the traffic information propagates across the network. Also, when a large number of V2V-capable vehicles seek to simultaneously exchange information in a small area, it leads to information congestion and damping, implying that information can die out. These insights can aid agencies to develop "intelligent" solutions that target poorly-performing areas of a traffic network.
